awd_titl_txt: Organic Aerosol Dynamics: Molecular Interactions, Single Particles and Modest Driving Forces
awd_abstract_narration:
Fine particles play a key role in atmospheric chemistry, and effect human health and weather. The physical and chemical properties of fine particles are critical in controlling their behavior. The properties of these particles are significantly different from liquids or solids. Typical particles are about 300 nanometers in diameter and contain roughly 10 million individual molecules. Well over half of those molecules are organic (carbon containing) compounds, and even a single particle often contains hundreds of thousands of different organic molecules, most of which have never been isolated or synthesized by chemists. These organic molecules stick to the tiny particles rather than letting go of the particle and floating (volatilizing) into the air. Some of the organic compounds resemble asphalt or complex sugars.  This research advances fundamental understanding of how combustion processes and products related to energy production may influence human health.    

Professor Neil Donahue and his graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University study the behavior of a number of model systems using sophisticated mass spectrometers that can measure the composition of individual 300 nm particles along with complementary chemical ionization mass spectrometers that can measure individual molecules in the gas and particle phases. They generate organic particles mimicking those found in the atmosphere with progressively higher degrees of oxidation to see if the particles become more viscous in a way that matters - by directly testing if semi-volatile organics can diffuse into the particles and whether two initially distinct populations of particles with semi-volatile constituents evolve toward each other because of mixing. The researchers conduct these experiments over a wide range of relative humidity conditions as humidity varies widely in the atmosphere and because wet particles are known to be much less viscous and more diffusive. Via a collaboration with colleagues at Northwestern University, they use synthesized molecules containing the stable carbon isotope, 13C, to cleanly separate molecules from different particle populations using mass spectrometry. The project prepares doctoral students for a research career. Professor Donahue is an ambassador in the Science and Engineering Ambassadors Program founded by the National Academies. He brings a focus on the coupling between energy use and environmental health issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Aerosol particles between a few nanometers and several micrometers in diameter play an outsized role in atmospheric chemistry and air pollution. Inhallation of particles and deposition in the deep lung induces cardiovascular distress that kills up to 7 million people anually. Aerosol particles have strong climate effects because they scatter light directly (especially when they swell with water) and because they serve as seeds for cloud droplets and thus govern cloud albedo (reflectivity). Aerosols also evolve in the atmosphere via condensation of vapors and via multiphase chemistry that requires either uptake of oxidants into particles or diffusion of particle constituents to the particle surface. Diffusivity within particles is thus a critical property, but it is difficult to measure directly. Recent research based on indirect measures (particle viscosity or bounce) has led researchers to conclude that diffusion limitations into "glassy" organic particles is common.

This project continued development of a novel method based on intercombination of two distinct particle populations that can be distinguished using single-particle mass spectrometery. A semi-volatile constituent (or constituents) on at least one population can be tracked as they either do or do not diffuse into the opposite population, in ammounts that cannot be due to simple surface coating and thus must be due to diffusion into the target particles. This research project focused on aerosol populations with at least some physical properties that are well constrained in order to more accurately separate thermodynamic effects (activity coefficients / miscibility), physical effects (vapor pressure / volatility) and actual diffusivity. This included using ionic liquid particles with negligible vapor pressure but ensured high diffusivity and  particles with single sugars coating easily distinguished inorganic seeds of ammonium sulfate and black carbon. We consistently observed diffusion of semi-volatile polyol molecules into coatings even of very viscous trisaccharide sugars well below their glass transition temperature, calling into question common assumptions about diffusion limitations.

In addition to providing fundamental methods and measurements, the findings have extended impasts to human health and climate effects, and the methodology was extended to ambient measurements in an urban setting to identify highly externally mixed particle populations (particles with individual sources) from both traffic and cooking) that rapidly evolve over just 10s of km of transport to become internally mixed (particles with constituents from multiple different sources that are largely indistringuishable). The research also provided training for two doctoral students to start careers as researchers.
